hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_:
Puali‘i was angry and took the club and went until he reached the middle where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was kneeling, cooking his four sweet potato tubers on the fire. All the children saw this and ran and stood in a row to watch Puali‘i. Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Here is the club in my hand, it will strike your head today, and your head will be cut off, and then it will be cooked with sweet potatoes, and I will eat it first, and then it will be freed.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not listen to Puali‘i's words, and Puali‘i spoke again, this time in anger. Puali‘i was ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the club, at the time when Nāmakaokapāo‘o was praying his death prayer for Puali‘i. The prayer was as follows: 
Love only the eyes of my pāo‘o fish,
Swollen and rough is the surface,
Maybe eaten, maybe left,
Maybe left to Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,
My pāo‘o fish eyes are for my lover,
Nāmakaokai‘a is the high chief of Hawai‘i,
Go away, go away, only the humble ones,
The people with the spear,
The spear with the drum,
Die to Nāmakaokapāo‘o.

**Paragraph 7:**
• The events in this paragraph unfold rapidly, showcasing the intense animosity between Puali‘i and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, amid a backdrop of power struggle and generational conflict, characteristic of the 'Ai Kapu era.
– Puali‘i, driven by anger, takes the club (ko‘ilipi), an object often associated with strength, authority, and warfare, and approaches Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, who is engaged in a mundane yet crucial activity – cooking sweet potatoes, a staple food in Hawaiian culture, symbolizing nourishment and sustenance.
• The mention of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o cooking four sweet potato tubers is intriguing, as it might allude to the four cardinal directions or the four primary stages of life in Hawaiian cosmology, signifying a connection to the land, the divine, and the cyclical nature of life.
– The act of cooking, especially sweet potatoes, holds spiritual significance, as it represents transformation and growth, mirroring the themes of personal and societal evolution that permeate this narrative.
• Puali‘i's threat to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, involving the club, decapitation, and the consumption of his head with sweet potatoes, is a stark, violent image that conjures the specter of human sacrifice, a practice associated with the 'Ai Kapu period, highlighting the deep-seated cultural and generational conflicts at play.
– This threat can also be seen as an allegory for the struggle between the old, rigid 'Ai Kapu system and the emerging, more progressive societal norms, with Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o representing change and Puali‘i embodying the resistance to it.
• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o's prayer, directed at Puali‘i, is laden with symbolic language and metaphorical references, showcasing the complex spiritual and cultural tapestry of ancient Hawaiian society.
– The invocation of the pāo‘o fish eyes as a symbol of love and the reference to Nākukui‘aimakaokalani, a figure possibly associated with divine or ancestral lineage, underscore the deep connection between the individual, the land, and the divine in Hawaiian belief systems.
– The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o itself, with Nā-maka- (the eyes) -o- (of) -ka- (the) -pāo‘o (a type of fish), may symbolize clarity, foresight, or the ability to navigate through challenging situations, reflecting the protagonist's role as a harbinger of change.
• The prayer's conclusion, with its wish for the death of Puali‘i, marks a turning point in their conflict, symbolizing the inevitable clash between the forces of tradition and those of innovation, setting the stage for the events that will unfold in the narrative.
– The mention of Nāmakaokai‘a as the high chief of Hawai‘i introduces the theme of leadership and the rightful governance of the land, hinting at the broader political and societal transformations that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o's story may allegorically represent.
raw_response:
<translation>Puali‘i was angry and took the club and went until he reached the middle where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was kneeling, cooking his four sweet potato tubers on the fire. All the children saw this and ran and stood in a row to watch Puali‘i. Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Here is the club in my hand, it will strike your head today, and your head will be cut off, and then it will be cooked with sweet potatoes, and I will eat it first, and then it will be freed.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not listen to Puali‘i's words, and Puali‘i spoke again, this time in anger. Puali‘i was ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the club, at the time when Nāmakaokapāo‘o was praying his death prayer for Puali‘i. The prayer was as follows: 
Love only the eyes of my pāo‘o fish,
Swollen and rough is the surface,
Maybe eaten, maybe left,
Maybe left to Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,
My pāo‘o fish eyes are for my lover,
Nāmakaokai‘a is the high chief of Hawai‘i,
Go away, go away, only the humble ones,
The people with the spear,
The spear with the drum,
Die to Nāmakaokapāo‘o.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 7:**
• The events in this paragraph unfold rapidly, showcasing the intense animosity between Puali‘i and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, amid a backdrop of power struggle and generational conflict, characteristic of the 'Ai Kapu era.
– Puali‘i, driven by anger, takes the club (ko‘ilipi), an object often associated with strength, authority, and warfare, and approaches Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, who is engaged in a mundane yet crucial activity – cooking sweet potatoes, a staple food in Hawaiian culture, symbolizing nourishment and sustenance.
• The mention of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o cooking four sweet potato tubers is intriguing, as it might allude to the four cardinal directions or the four primary stages of life in Hawaiian cosmology, signifying a connection to the land, the divine, and the cyclical nature of life.
– The act of cooking, especially sweet potatoes, holds spiritual significance, as it represents transformation and growth, mirroring the themes of personal and societal evolution that permeate this narrative.
• Puali‘i's threat to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, involving the club, decapitation, and the consumption of his head with sweet potatoes, is a stark, violent image that conjures the specter of human sacrifice, a practice associated with the 'Ai Kapu period, highlighting the deep-seated cultural and generational conflicts at play.
– This threat can also be seen as an allegory for the struggle between the old, rigid 'Ai Kapu system and the emerging, more progressive societal norms, with Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o representing change and Puali‘i embodying the resistance to it.
• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o's prayer, directed at Puali‘i, is laden with symbolic language and metaphorical references, showcasing the complex spiritual and cultural tapestry of ancient Hawaiian society.
– The invocation of the pāo‘o fish eyes as a symbol of love and the reference to Nākukui‘aimakaokalani, a figure possibly associated with divine or ancestral lineage, underscore the deep connection between the individual, the land, and the divine in Hawaiian belief systems.
– The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o itself, with Nā-maka- (the eyes) -o- (of) -ka- (the) -pāo‘o (a type of fish), may symbolize clarity, foresight, or the ability to navigate through challenging situations, reflecting the protagonist's role as a harbinger of change.
• The prayer's conclusion, with its wish for the death of Puali‘i, marks a turning point in their conflict, symbolizing the inevitable clash between the forces of tradition and those of innovation, setting the stage for the events that will unfold in the narrative.
– The mention of Nāmakaokai‘a as the high chief of Hawai‘i introduces the theme of leadership and the rightful governance of the land, hinting at the broader political and societal transformations that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o's story may allegorically represent.</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
